Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Not So Fast - Historical Biogeography of Freshwater Fishes in Central America and the Greater Antilles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Central America/Greater Antilles region, including Puerto Rico, has one of the most complex geological histories in the world, with extinct and current landbridges, drifting island chains and many moving parts over the last 70 million years. With over 500 species of freshwater fishes,this region can inform us about this complicated history because the fish are typically restricted to freshwater habitats on those moving landmasses (i.e., they can only move among areas that are physically connected). Thus, the history of freshwater fishes can help reveal the complex history of the islands and landmasses that currently make up the Central American landbridge and the Greater Antillean islands. This project will help researchers better understand the impact of the separation of the Caribbean Sea and the Pacific Ocean and the connection of North and South America by what is now Central America and potentially by earlier landbridges. Researchers will gain a better understanding of how unique historical events can result in mass species diversification or mass extinction, and how the formation of dispersal corridors can degrade biotic provincialism. Working with local Caribbean and Latin American colleagues as well as student members of their own labs, researchers will use this evolutionary, taxonomic and geographic knowledge to determine the conservation status of these poorly understood and potentially threatened lineages of fish species. The conservation status will be used by local and national governments to prioritize conservation actions for added societal benefit.

In this study, researchers will collect specimens of the regions freshwater fishes in order to obtain DNA and morphological specimens for museums. Phylogenetic relationships will be estimated using a next-generation sequencing approach applied to several hundred species. These analyses will include species tree estimation, divergence date estimations and historical biogeographical analyses. This synthetic analysis will determine the relationships and historical processes leading to present patterns of diversity. The results will be distributed through scientific publications, databases and Encyclopedia of Life species pages. Thousands of museum specimens, next-generation genomic markers, and newly developed phylogenetic and biogeographic programs will be made available as the products of this work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Central America (the landbridge that connects North and South America and that includes the countries between Mexico and Colombia) and the Greater Antilles (the Caribbean Islands of Cuba, Hispaniola, Puerto Rico and Jamaica) have some of the most complex geological histories of any landmasses on Earth; the different geological hypotheses about past connections between these Northern Neotropical landmasses can be tested by examining the evolutionary histories of the freshwater fishes that live in this region. Freshwater fishes, because they are often limited to breeding and dispersing in freshwaters, can help us explore ancient geological history when the relationships of these animals reveal patterns that show support for one hypothesis over others. Using innovative phylogenomic techniques (e.g., next-generation genetic sequencing methods including the use of ultraconserved elements), conducting fieldwork and collaborations across eight Neotropical countries, and with the training of several postdocs and students, we found evidence that a mix of ancient vicariant and more recent dispersal events explained the distribution of the roughly 300 species of obligate freshwater fish species from Central America and the Greater Antilles. Among the major findings of this project were: (1) The Closure of the Isthmus of Panama, a major event that connected the American continents, may have begun much earlier than previously thought; (2) fine-scale biogeographic analyses revealed a new area of endemism in northern Central America: the Grijalva–Usumacinta; (3) poeciliids and cichlids (the two groups of freshwater fishes that dominate Central America and the Caribbean) arrived in Central America long before the commonly cited Plio-Pleistocene rise of the Isthmus of Panama and may have used freshwater plumes across marine barriers or ancient landbridges to aid their dispersal from South America; (4) we find no support for the GAARlandia landbridge (that existed about 34–33 million years ago) playing a major role in aiding the dispersal of freshwater fishes in the Northern Neotropics.

In addition, as a result of this project, new species and genera were described, and new threats including invasive species and future climate change impacts were documented in the freshwaters of the Northern Neotropics. This project built scientific infrastructure by training many junior scientists in the U.S. and abroad, and by forging collaborations between U.S. and Latin American colleagues. The specimens collected and housed both in the U.S. and abroad will help supply future evidence and materials for DNA and morphology-based research for many years to come.
